body:
There are two possible memory issues here with regards to autograd. (1) unnecessary forward data is saved, which should be fixed by https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/commit/7d6385a515dbda096560271628abf34e91e9be63 ; (2) backward memory cannot reuse forward memory since autograd requires a standalone backward graph to be executed. I would try two things:
(1) Make sure that using pure symbols give the same memory consumption as tf+keras. For example, you can try use SymbolBlock.
(2) Do forward with autograd turned on, but without calling "compute_gradient". In this case, the forward data required by backward will be saved.

If both (1) and (2) have the same memory consumption compared with tf+keras, then the reason might due to forward and backward memory cannot be reused in autograd mode.

You can use print_summary() from visualization.py
Usage:
`mxnet.visualization.print_summary(<NeuralNetSymbol>, shape={'data':(100,3,28,28)})`
_shape_ is Input shape of data that should be a dictionary with the key as _data_ and the value as
_no of instances, channels, height, width_.

@reminisce @piiswrong @mli

This variable is borrowed from caffe: https://github.com/BVLC/caffe/blob/master/src/caffe/layers/base_conv_layer.cpp#L110, where it is used to skip col_buff memory allocation in the 1x1 kernel case. If it's really a common use case, we should do the optimization as in caffe as well.

This PR causes all builds to fail at sanity check step

I was in the process of switching the 21 uses of dot() over to linalg_gemm when I noticed this change.  If the preferred long-term interface is linalg_gemm, why don't I just modify linalg_impl.h to check MSHADOW_USE_CBLAS and invoke dot(), rather than have this ifdef sequence repeated in many places?
@DickJC123 Yeah I think that's reasonable. A better solution would be to copy the dot implementation into mxnet and use it from linalg_gemm when blas is not available.

I would prefer to limit the scope of the change I'm working on, so I'll go forward with my suggestion.  I'll leave it to another time/person to copy the dot implementation from mshadow, if that remains desirable.

[The 3.2 section](https://arxiv.org/abs/1704.04861) of Mobilenet paper have mentioned that. I found the 1x1 convolution(with stride 1 and pad 0) is commonly used in almost all modern networks such as Googlenet/Inception/Resnet/ResNeXt too. When these networks are used in detection or segmetation, the intermediate feature maps will become very large, so the im2col skipped 1x1 convolution operation might save a lot of memory and computing resource.

For me the case was that I had trained the model using one batch size and then tried to evaluate using a different one.

E.g.

```python
train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(X_train, y_train, batch_size, shuffle=True)
test_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(X_test, y_test, batch_size)
```

Note how I assign the same batch size to both iterators. When I tried using different batch sizes it would error out. Not sure if this is a bug or not, I don't see why the batch size needs to be tied to the model after training.

As there is no nd.randint,symbol in mxnet, you can define a sym.Variable('mask') to store mask. Then, you can generate mask tensor with numpy.randint as mask input during training. When testing, you can set all values of mask 1.

Absolutely you can define a 0-1-mask layer with reference to [https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/example/numpy-ops/custom_softmax.py](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/example/numpy-ops/custom_softmax.py).
"error C2768" showed with linalg_gemm in "linalg_impl.h" in Windows.
I see. @dtmoodie you need to include operator.h insteand op.h.

I have similar issue when i use tensorflow, even when i set the cuda/lib64 path in ~/.bashrc. The below code works for me. You can have a try. Path is the cuda lib64 that may be different from yours.
```
sudo sh -c "echo '/usr/local/cuda/lib64\n/usr/local/cuda/lib' >> /etc/ld.so.conf.d/nvidia.conf"
sudo ldconfig
```

error LNK2019
"void __cdecl linalg_batch_trsm"
"void __cdecl linalg_batch_gemm"

If I would do this, then I'd have the same mask for every iteration / batch. 
This would be equal to corrupt my data directly (outside the net by corruption a fraction of p) and then plug it into the net.
This has the huge disadvantage, that if any observation is drawn more than once, the corruption pattern is guaranteed the same (thus not random) and the net doesn't learn a generalization to fill in the gaps. 

But if the intention is to generate a new corruption mask _every time a new batch is drawn_ this won't work either. 

To clarify: The final result will be a stacked denoising autoencoder (SDAE), whereas no example for MXNetR exists so far.

In caffe, only "mirror" is specified in the prototxt configuration, when in trainning, the image was resize to 256*256, and then random crop to 224*224

In mxnet, I use the default setting in the data augumentation, and also 256*256 to 224*224 by random crop as I know

I want to use CaffeOP to transfer the original caffe network to mxnet, but I don't know whether it is effective, Now I am doing this task!

In mxnet, I use the default setting in the data augumentation, and also 256256 to 224224 by random crop as I know


I want to use CaffeOP to transfer the original caffe network to mxnet, but I don't know whether it is effective, Now I am doing this task!
@reminisce PR is pushed. #7613

I notice that in PyToch DataLoader, there is a parameter named num_worker, but in Gluon DataLoader, there is no such a parameter. This parameter can do multiprocess work. If I set `num_works = 0`, then PyTorch need about 100 s. So I think this is one of the reason why Gluon is much slower than PyTorch. But even if PyTorch needs 100 s, it's still faster than gluon, so I think there may be some problems.
